canonical_explanation.text: Motion in a straight line (rectilinear motion) is the simplest form of motion. Position of an object is described relative to a chosen origin in a frame of reference. Distance is the total path length traversed (scalar, always positive), while displacement is the change in position (vector, can be positive, negative, or zero). Speed is the rate of change of distance, while velocity is the rate of change of displacement. Average velocity = total displacement / total time = (x₂ − x₁)/(t₂ − t₁). Instantaneous velocity is the limit of average velocity as the time interval approaches zero: v = dx/dt. Similarly, average speed = total distance / total time. Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity: a = dv/dt = d²x/dt². For uniformly accelerated motion (constant acceleration), the three kinematic equations are: v = u + at, s = ut + ½at², and v² = u² + 2as, where u is initial velocity, v is final velocity, a is acceleration, t is time, and s is displacement. The displacement in the nth second is sₙ = u + a(2n−1)/2. Position-time graphs: slope gives velocity; velocity-time graphs: slope gives acceleration and area under the curve gives displacement. Free fall is motion under gravity alone with acceleration g ≈ 9.8 m/s² directed downward. For a body thrown vertically upward with velocity u, maximum height H = u²/(2g), time of ascent = u/g, and total time of flight = 2u/g. The body returns with the same speed it was thrown with.
rules: Displacement is a vector; distance is a scalar and always ≥ |displacement|.
Average velocity = Δx/Δt; average speed = total distance / total time.
Instantaneous velocity v = dx/dt; instantaneous acceleration a = dv/dt.
For uniform acceleration: v = u + at.
Displacement in nth second: sₙ = u + a(2n − 1)/2.
Slope of x-t graph = velocity; slope of v-t graph = acceleration.
Free fall: a = g = 9.8 m/s² downward; maximum height H = u²/(2g).
Time of flight for vertical throw = 2u/g.

questions.question_text: A particle moves along a straight line from point A to point B (10 m apart) and then returns to a point C which is 4 m from A. The distance and displacement of the particle are:
questions.explanation_correct: Distance = AB + BC = 10 + 6 = 16 m. Displacement = AC = 4 m (from A towards B).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Distance is total path length (10 + 6 = 16 m), not just one-way. Displacement is the straight-line distance from start to finish = 4 m, not 6 m or 10 m.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: Displacement can be greater than distance
Distance is always greater than or equal to the magnitude of displacement
Distance and displacement are always equal

questions.explanation_correct: Distance (total path length) is always ≥ |displacement| because the shortest path between two points is a straight line.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Distance is always non-negative and can never be less than |displacement|. Displacement can be zero even when distance is not.

questions.question_text: A body completes one full revolution along a circular path of radius 7 m. The distance and magnitude of displacement are:
questions.explanation_correct: Distance = circumference = 2πr = 2 × 22/7 × 7 = 44 m. Since the body returns to the starting point, displacement = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: After one full revolution the body is back at the start, so displacement is zero. But the total path length (distance) is the full circumference = 44 m.

questions.question_text: A person walks 4 m east, then 3 m north along a straight path. The magnitude of displacement is:
questions.explanation_correct: Displacement = √(4² + 3²) = √(16 + 9) = √25 = 5 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Distance is 4 + 3 = 7 m, but displacement is the straight-line distance from start to end = √(4² + 3²) = 5 m.

questions.question_text: In which of the following cases is the distance equal to the magnitude of displacement?

options.text: A body moving in a circle
A body moving in a straight line without changing direction
A body moving along a curved path
A body oscillating back and forth

questions.explanation_correct: When a body moves in a straight line without reversing direction, the path length equals the magnitude of displacement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For circular, curved, or oscillatory motion the path length exceeds the straight-line displacement.

questions.question_text: A particle starts from the origin, goes to x = +5 m, then to x = −3 m, and finally to x = +2 m. The ratio of distance to magnitude of displacement is:
questions.explanation_correct: Distance = 5 + 8 + 5 = 18 m. Displacement = final − initial = 2 − 0 = 2 m. Ratio = 18/2 = 9.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Total distance includes all segments: 0→5 (5 m), 5→−3 (8 m), −3→2 (5 m) = 18 m. Displacement is just final position = 2 m.

questions.question_text: The position of a particle is given by x = 3t² − 6t + 2 (x in metres, t in seconds). The displacement of the particle from t = 0 to t = 3 s is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Displacement = x(final) − x(initial) = 11 − 2 = 9 m. Distance would be different if the particle reverses direction.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a vector quantity?
questions.explanation_correct: Displacement is a vector quantity as it has both magnitude and direction. Distance, speed, and time are scalars.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Distance, speed, and time are all scalar quantities. Only displacement has both magnitude and direction.

questions.question_text: The displacement of a particle can be zero even if the distance covered is not zero. This happens when:

options.text: The particle moves in a straight line
The particle returns to its initial position
The particle moves with uniform velocity

questions.explanation_correct: When the particle returns to its starting point, the displacement (final position − initial position) is zero, but the total path length (distance) is non-zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Moving in a straight line or with uniform velocity still produces displacement. At rest, both distance and displacement are zero.

questions.question_text: A car moves 40 km due north and then 30 km due east. The ratio of distance to displacement is:
questions.explanation_correct: Distance = 40 + 30 = 70 km. Displacement = √(40² + 30²) = √(2500) = 50 km. Ratio = 70/50 = 7/5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Distance is the total path (70 km), not the straight-line distance. Displacement = √(1600 + 900) = 50 km.

questions.question_text: A car travels 120 km in 2 hours. Its average speed is:
questions.explanation_correct: Average speed = total distance / total time = 120/2 = 60 km/h.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Average speed is simply distance divided by time, giving 120/2 = 60 km/h.

questions.question_text: If the displacement of a body is zero over a time interval, its average velocity is:
questions.explanation_correct: Average velocity = displacement / time. If displacement = 0, average velocity = 0 regardless of the distance covered.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Average velocity depends on displacement, not distance. Zero displacement means zero average velocity.

questions.question_text: The instantaneous velocity of a particle is defined as:

options.text: The limit of Δx/Δt as Δt approaches zero
Average speed at a given time

questions.explanation_correct: Instantaneous velocity v = lim(Δt→0) Δx/Δt = dx/dt, which is the derivative of position with respect to time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Total distance/time gives average speed, not instantaneous velocity. The slope of the x-t graph (not x-t²) gives velocity.

questions.question_text: A body covers the first half of a distance at 40 km/h and the second half at 60 km/h. The average speed for the entire journey is:
questions.explanation_correct: For equal distances d: total time = d/40 + d/60 = (3d + 2d)/120 = 5d/120. Average speed = 2d/(5d/120) = 240/5 = 48 km/h.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The average is not the arithmetic mean (50). For equal distances, use harmonic mean: 2×40×60/(40+60) = 4800/100 = 48 km/h.

questions.question_text: A body covers the first half of total time at 20 m/s and the second half at 30 m/s. The average speed is:
questions.explanation_correct: For equal times t: total distance = 20t + 30t = 50t. Total time = 2t. Average speed = 50t/2t = 25 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When time intervals are equal, average speed is the arithmetic mean: (20 + 30)/2 = 25 m/s.

questions.question_text: The position of a particle is given by x = 2t³ − 3t² + t (in metres). The instantaneous velocity at t = 2 s is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Instantaneous velocity is the derivative of position: v = 6t² − 6t + 1. At t = 2, this gives 13 m/s.

questions.question_text: A particle moves such that its position x = 4t − t² (m). The average velocity between t = 0 and t = 3 s is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Average velocity = Δx/Δt = [x(3) − x(0)] / 3 = 3/3 = 1 m/s.

questions.question_text: Can the average speed of a body be zero if the body has moved?

options.text: Yes, if the body returns to its starting point
No, average speed can never be zero if the body has moved

questions.explanation_correct: Average speed = total distance / total time. Since distance is always positive for a moving body, average speed cannot be zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Average velocity can be zero if the body returns to start, but average speed (based on distance, not displacement) is always positive if the body has moved.

questions.question_text: The speedometer of a car measures:
questions.explanation_correct: A speedometer reads the instantaneous speed of the vehicle at any moment, not the average or the velocity (which requires direction).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The speedometer gives the speed at that instant, not averaged over the journey. It shows magnitude only, not direction.

questions.question_text: A train covers a distance of 15 km at a uniform speed of 60 km/h, then the next 15 km at 40 km/h, and the last 15 km at 30 km/h. The average speed of the train is:
questions.explanation_correct: Total distance = 45 km. Total time = 15/60 + 15/40 + 15/30 = 0.25 + 0.375 + 0.5 = 1.125 h. Average speed = 45/1.125 = 40 km/h.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Average speed for unequal speeds over equal distances is not the arithmetic mean. Total time = 1.125 h, so avg speed = 45/1.125 = 40 km/h.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct equation of motion for uniformly accelerated motion?
questions.explanation_correct: The first equation of motion is v = u + at, where u is initial velocity, v is final velocity, a is acceleration, and t is time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct first equation is v = u + at. The term at (not at² or ½at) gives the change in velocity.

questions.question_text: A body starting from rest accelerates uniformly at 2 m/s². The velocity after 5 seconds is:
questions.explanation_correct: Using v = u + at: v = 0 + 2 × 5 = 10 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Starting from rest means u = 0. So v = at = 2 × 5 = 10 m/s, not 25 (which would be the distance) or 50.

questions.question_text: A car moving at 20 m/s is brought to rest in 4 s. The acceleration of the car is:
questions.explanation_correct: a = (v − u)/t = (0 − 20)/4 = −5 m/s². The negative sign indicates deceleration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since the car decelerates, acceleration is negative: a = (0 − 20)/4 = −5 m/s².

questions.question_text: A body starting from rest moves with uniform acceleration of 3 m/s². The distance covered in 4 seconds is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using s = ut + ½at² with u = 0: s = ½ × 3 × 16 = 24 m.

questions.question_text: A car accelerates from 10 m/s to 30 m/s over a distance of 200 m. The acceleration is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: v² − u² = 2as gives 900 − 100 = 400a, so a = 800/400 = 2 m/s².

questions.question_text: A body with initial velocity 5 m/s and acceleration 2 m/s² covers a distance in the 4th second equal to:
A body starting from rest travels distances in ratio 1 : 3 : 5 : 7 in successive equal time intervals. This implies the body is moving with:
questions.explanation_correct: For uniformly accelerated motion from rest, distances in successive equal time intervals are in ratio 1:3:5:7:... (odd numbers). This is a characteristic of constant acceleration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ratio 1:3:5:7 for successive equal time intervals is a hallmark of uniform acceleration from rest.

questions.question_text: A train moving at 72 km/h is brought to rest by applying brakes in 10 s. The distance covered during braking is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Convert 72 km/h to 20 m/s. Using s = (u + v)t/2 = (20 + 0)(10)/2 = 100 m.

questions.question_text: Two bodies start from rest and move with accelerations a₁ and a₂. If they cover the same distance in times t₁ and t₂ respectively, then t₁/t₂ equals:
questions.explanation_correct: s = ½a₁t₁² = ½a₂t₂². So a₁t₁² = a₂t₂², giving t₁/t₂ = √(a₂/a₁).
questions.explanation_incorrect: From ½a₁t₁² = ½a₂t₂², we get t₁²/t₂² = a₂/a₁, hence t₁/t₂ = √(a₂/a₁).

questions.question_text: The SI unit of acceleration is:
questions.explanation_correct: Acceleration = change in velocity / time = (m/s)/s = m/s².
questions.explanation_incorrect: m/s is the unit of velocity. Acceleration has dimensions of velocity/time, giving m/s².

questions.question_text: The slope of a position-time graph gives:
questions.explanation_correct: Slope of x-t graph = Δx/Δt = velocity. For instantaneous velocity, it is the slope of the tangent at that point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The slope of position vs. time gives velocity (rate of change of position), not acceleration (which is slope of v-t graph).

questions.question_text: The area under a velocity-time graph gives:
questions.explanation_correct: Area under v-t graph = ∫v dt = displacement. If the graph goes below the time axis, that area represents negative displacement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The integral of velocity with respect to time gives displacement. The slope of v-t graph gives acceleration.

questions.question_text: A straight horizontal line on a velocity-time graph represents:
questions.explanation_correct: A horizontal line on a v-t graph means velocity is constant, implying zero acceleration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A horizontal line means no change in velocity. A sloped straight line would indicate uniform (constant) acceleration.

questions.question_text: The velocity-time graph of a body is a straight line passing through the origin with a positive slope. This indicates:

options.text: The body starts from rest and has uniform acceleration

questions.explanation_correct: Line through origin means v = 0 at t = 0 (starts from rest). Constant positive slope means constant acceleration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A straight line through the origin on a v-t graph means v ∝ t, i.e., the body starts from rest with constant acceleration.

questions.question_text: In a position-time graph, a parabolic curve opening upward indicates:

options.text: Uniform acceleration in the positive direction

questions.explanation_correct: x = ut + ½at² is a parabola in t. An upward-opening parabola on x-t graph indicates positive acceleration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Uniform velocity gives a straight line on x-t graph. A parabola indicates changing velocity, i.e., non-zero acceleration.

questions.question_text: The velocity-time graph of a body is shown as a triangle with base along the time axis from t = 0 to t = 10 s and peak velocity 20 m/s at t = 5 s. The total displacement is:
questions.explanation_correct: Displacement = area of triangle = ½ × base × height = ½ × 10 × 20 = 100 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The area under the v-t graph gives displacement. For a triangle: ½ × 10 × 20 = 100 m.

questions.question_text: A body moves with velocity 10 m/s for 5 s, then decelerates uniformly to rest in the next 5 s. The position-time graph for this motion would be:

options.text: A straight line followed by a parabola
A parabola followed by a straight line

questions.explanation_correct: Uniform velocity gives a straight line on x-t graph. Uniform deceleration gives a parabolic x-t curve.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The first phase (constant velocity) is linear on x-t. The second phase (uniform deceleration) is parabolic.

questions.question_text: The slope of the tangent to the position-time curve at any instant gives the instantaneous velocity. If the x-t curve is concave upward, the acceleration is:
questions.explanation_correct: A concave upward x-t curve means the slope (velocity) is increasing with time, which implies positive acceleration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Concave upward means d²x/dt² > 0, i.e., acceleration is positive. Concave downward would mean negative acceleration.

questions.question_text: A velocity-time graph shows a straight line with negative slope that crosses the time axis. This means:

options.text: The body accelerates, stops, then reverses direction
The body decelerates, stops momentarily, then moves in the opposite direction
The body moves with constant velocity
The body is at rest throughout

questions.explanation_correct: Negative slope on v-t graph means constant deceleration. Crossing the time axis means v = 0 momentarily, then velocity becomes negative (reversal).
questions.explanation_incorrect: When the v-t line crosses the t-axis, the body momentarily stops and then reverses. The negative slope indicates uniform deceleration/retardation.

questions.question_text: The slope of a velocity-time graph gives:
questions.explanation_correct: Slope of v-t graph = Δv/Δt = acceleration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The rate of change of velocity is acceleration. The area under v-t graph gives displacement, not the slope.

questions.question_text: The acceleration due to gravity on Earth is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The acceleration due to gravity near Earth's surface is g ≈ 9.8 m/s², directed vertically downward.
questions.explanation_incorrect: g is an acceleration and has SI units of m/s², not m/s (speed) or m²/s or km/s².

questions.question_text: A ball is dropped from rest. After 2 seconds, its velocity is (take g = 10 m/s²):
questions.explanation_correct: v = u + gt = 0 + 10 × 2 = 20 m/s (downward).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Starting from rest (u = 0), v = gt = 10 × 2 = 20 m/s.

questions.question_text: In free fall, which of the following is true (ignoring air resistance)?

options.text: All objects fall with the same acceleration

questions.explanation_correct: In the absence of air resistance, all objects experience the same gravitational acceleration g regardless of their mass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Galileo demonstrated that in vacuum, all bodies fall with equal acceleration irrespective of mass.

questions.question_text: A ball is thrown vertically upward with a velocity of 49 m/s. The maximum height reached is (g = 9.8 m/s²):
questions.explanation_correct: At max height v = 0. Using v² = u² − 2gH: 0 = 49² − 2(9.8)H. H = 2401/19.6 = 122.5 m.

questions.question_text: A stone is thrown vertically upward with a velocity of 20 m/s. The time taken to reach the highest point is (g = 10 m/s²):
questions.explanation_correct: At highest point v = 0. Using v = u − gt: 0 = 20 − 10t, so t = 2 s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Time of ascent = u/g = 20/10 = 2 s. Total time of flight would be 4 s.

questions.question_text: A ball dropped from a tower of height 80 m reaches the ground in (g = 10 m/s²):
questions.explanation_correct: Using h = ½gt²: 80 = ½(10)t² = 5t². t² = 16. t = 4 s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: From h = ½gt², we get t = √(2h/g) = √(160/10) = √16 = 4 s.

questions.question_text: A body is thrown vertically upward. At the highest point:

options.text: Both velocity and acceleration are zero
Velocity is zero but acceleration is g downward
Velocity is maximum and acceleration is zero
Both velocity and acceleration are directed downward

questions.explanation_correct: At the highest point, velocity momentarily becomes zero, but acceleration due to gravity (g = 9.8 m/s² downward) acts at all times during the motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acceleration due to gravity is always present (9.8 m/s² downward), even at the highest point. Only velocity becomes zero.

questions.question_text: Two balls are dropped from heights h₁ and h₂ (h₁ > h₂). The ratio of times taken to reach the ground is:
questions.explanation_correct: h = ½gt², so t = √(2h/g). Ratio t₁/t₂ = √(h₁)/√(h₂) = √(h₁/h₂).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since t ∝ √h for free fall from rest, the ratio of times is the square root of the ratio of heights.

questions.question_text: A ball thrown vertically upward with speed u returns to the thrower after time T. The maximum height reached is:
questions.explanation_correct: Total time T = 2u/g, so u = gT/2. Max height H = u²/(2g) = (gT/2)²/(2g) = g²T²/(4 × 2g) = gT²/8.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since T = 2u/g, u = gT/2. Substituting in H = u²/(2g): H = g²T²/(8g) = gT²/8.

questions.question_text: A stone dropped from a cliff takes 3 s to hit the ground. The height of the cliff is (g = 9.8 m/s²):
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using h = ½gt² = 0.5 × 9.8 × 9 = 44.1 m. This is the height of the cliff.
